Award.AwardTitle: RIT/NazEd Tech2Teach: Developing Institutional Commitment to STEM Teacher Preparation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This capacity building project is laying the foundation for a Learning Assistant (LA) program to attract talented STEM undergraduates to careers in secondary education. The LA program, developed at the University of Colorado-Boulder, combines classroom teaching experience, directed faculty mentorship, and formal instruction on the science of how people learn to dramatically increase student interest in secondary teaching careers. This project is taking a comprehensive approach: attracting undergraduate STEM majors at Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT), providing a path, Tech2Teach, through Nazareth College of Rochester to certification in secondary education, and developing connections with existing high school teacher groups to provide continuing support. The project has three specific goals
1. to educate and facilitate faculty development through peer group targeted workshops,
2. to develop critical infrastructure, including online resources and a new course on pedagogy, and implement an LA program, and
3. to extend and enhance existing collaborations with Nazareth College's School of Education (Tech2Teach) and the local Rochester Area Physics Teacher Out-Reach (RAPTOR).

The broad impact of this project lies in the large number of faculty and students directly affected by the proposed activities. The physics, biology, chemistry, and mathematics departments at RIT currently include 136 faculty and 853 undergraduate majors. Through an innovative social network analysis approach that identifies teaching peer groups, the project is involving more than 70 faculty in development workshops and seminars to prepare them to mentor students in the LA program. Deep support from all involved departments is enabling the project to reach more than 400 students, educating them about the possibilities of a career in secondary education. In the second year, an LA program will be initiated that will pair 16 students with faculty mentors in classes that affect up to 500 students in STEM classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tech2Teach was created to accomplish 2 things: to give RIT undergraduate STEM majors an exciting teaching experience to attract them to careers in secondary education and to create pathways with local schools of Education that would allow students to pursue these careers. A related goal was to impropve learning in introductory STEM courses at RIT, thus demonstrating value to RIT administration and ensuring the programs' long-term sustainability.

From 2013-2015 the program funded 96 Learning Assistants, undergraduates who helped faculty transform introductory classrooms. LAs affected all major science disciplines, including mathematics, physics, biology and chemistry. Students worked with faculty advisors to develop new classroom materials, create innovative assessments to demonstrate success, and engaged deeply with the teaching and learning process. Students took a new course, Science Education: Research and Practice, which gave them exposure to the research that lay behind the new, activity-based methods.

To promote secondary school education, connections were made with local STEM secondary educators, including the Rochester Area Physics Teacher Organization (RAPTOR). Teacher rountables were organized to bring students and teachers into contact, allowing teachers to tell students directly why they were happy to have pursued careers in secondary education. Articulation agreements were signed with Nazareth College and Ithaca College that enabled RIT students to begin taking education courses while enrolled at RIT. As a result, students now have multiple options to receive their MS.Ed. with certification within one year after graduation. 

Finally, LAs and faculty mentors have transformed over thirty introductory science and math courses, with remarkable success at improving the learning and retention of students. In Elements of Multivariable Calculus, a key course for Applied Science & Technology majors, the number of students successfully passing the class went from 57% to 83%. In physics, a calculus-based Introductory Physics II course saw the number of students failing cut in half, from 30% to 15%. Similar results were found Genetics, a foundational course in the School of Life Sciences, with the attrition rate falling from 32% to 15%.The impact on faculty and classrooms has been profound, and RIT is now funding the program in its entirety. 

As a result, the RIT Learning Assistant Program has become a national model. We are an active member in the International Learning Assistant Alliance, regularly sending faculty to international and regional workshop. In Spring of 2016 we will host the Learning Assistant Alliance Northeast Regional Workshop, welcoming faculty from as far away as Massachusetts, Illinois, Washington D.C., Pennsylvania and Maine to learn more about how to implement a successful LA program.

Finally, the program has succeeded in its primary goal of energizing RIT students about becoming secondary school teachers. Although only in its third year, the program has already sent 3 students on to graduate schools in education, with 2 already receiving their MS.Ed. and certificaiton. The collaboration with the local high school teachers and Schools of Education has created an awareness of career possibilities that did not exist three short years ago, and RIT is poised to address the critical national shortage in qualified high school teachers of science and math.
